thread.title: Jeremy Corbyn to launch bid to send Theresa May's final Brexit deal back to Brussels if Parliament opposes it
thread.title_full: Jeremy Corbyn to launch bid to send Theresa May's final Brexit deal back to Brussels if Parliament opposes it

author: Steven Swinford
title: Jeremy Corbyn to launch bid to send Theresa May's final Brexit deal back to Brussels if Parliament opposes it
text:
Jeremy Corbyn to launch bid to send Theresa May's final Brexit deal back to Brussels if Parliament opposes it Jeremy Corbyn, the Labour leader Steven Swinford , Deputy Political Editor 23 January 2017 • 10:00pm 
J eremy Corbyn is expected to launch a new bid to frustrate Brexit by forcing Theresa May to send her final deal back to Brussels if Parliament votes against it. 
The Supreme Court will on Tuesday morning return its judgement on whether Parliament should be given a vote before formal Brexit negotiations begin in March. 
Ministers expect to lose the case and are prepared to go to the Commons with an Article 50 bill within hours of judges announcing their ruling. 
Mr Corbyn is planning to table an amendment which would formally require the Government to commit to a second vote on the final terms of any deal before Britain leaves the EU. Article 50 ruling | What will it mean for Brexit? 
L abour wants the Government to hold the vote early enough for the deal to be sent back to Brussels so it can be "improved or amended". 
Eurosceptic Conservative MPs said that the the proposal is "absurd" and highlights Mr Corbyn's "muddled and chaotic thinking" on Brexit. 
Iain Duncan Smith, the former Work and Pensions Secretary, said: "The deal is the deal, it's a take it or leave it option. This is a classic weasley game of trying to say something relevant. 
"It is absurd. It is quite clear once they've been through all these tortuous negotiations that will be it. It would cause the whole thing to unravel. 
"It would undermine the whole negotiating position of the Government. It tells you all you need to know about Labour's muddled, chaotic thinking." At a glance | Theresa Mays 12-point Brexit plan ​ 
T he Labour leader has yet to decide whether he will force his MPs to vote in favour of Article 50 in the Commons. He suggested last week that there would be a three-line whip on the issue, but within hours his aides said no decisions had been taken. The Prime Minister's official spokeswoman said yesterday that she will stick to her timetable of triggering Article 50 by the end of March and "get on" with Brexit. Follow Telegraph News
